metadata.notes: Funeral/Memorial sermon for a former colleague and professor.

freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.score_explanation: 10 = Completely free from coercive judgments. 0 = Very dominant Critical Parent.
freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.analysis: The preacher avoids the 'shaming' voice. Even when quoting the law-heavy Ephesians text, it is framed as a description of the deceased rather than a list of demands for the audience.
quotes: It is not hard to imagine that Paul has in mind Lowell when he wrote those words.

healthy_care_NP.score_explanation: 10 = Healthy, non-smothering care. 0 = Absent or smothering.
healthy_care_NP.analysis: The Nurturing Parent is strong, providing comfort through the legacy of the deceased. It promotes autonomy by presenting Lowell as a 'summons' rather than a command.
quotes: God welcomes all with abiding presence... Lowell is among them because he had already done the work of resonance.

adult.analysis: The preacher operates as an Adult historian and observer. He processes data about the deceased's life, faculty dynamics, and historical traditions objectively.
quotes: He taught us that the tradition of Pietism in which Eden stands was an irenic community of faith...
I figured out... that I would never be the senior member of the faculty.

freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.score_explanation: 10 = Free from fear/compliance. 0 = Strong Adapted Child (fear culture).
freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.analysis: The preacher admits his own faults ('wounded by some of us, certainly by me'), showing a lack of the need to appear 'perfect' or compliant to a rigid religious persona.
quotes: I am very sure that he was sometimes wounded by some of us, certainly by me.

free_child_FC.analysis: Authentic joy and 'puckishness' are celebrated. The preacher connects with the deceased's Free Child (humor, arts) and invites the congregation to a similar authentic resonance.
quotes: I could enjoy his puckish good humor

transaction_analysis.analysis: The preacher speaks as one colleague to others, sharing historical insights and personal observations. He invites the listener to reflect on a life lived, rather than demanding a specific emotional or behavioral response.
transaction_analysis.ulterior_motives: None detected. The social message (celebrating a life) matches the psychological message (invitation to peace).
transaction_analysis.risk_explanation: The only slight risk is the 'halo effect' where the deceased is presented as so perfect that the listener might feel an Adapted Child pressure to emulate an impossible standard, but the preacher's admission of his own 'rough and tumble' behavior mitigates this.

games_analysis.absence_of_games_analysis: The sermon maintains authenticity by avoiding the 'Bait & Switch'. It uses the scripture not as a trap to catch sinners, but as a lens to view a human life. There is no 'NIGYSOB' because the preacher includes himself in the group of people who are 'wounded' or 'perplexed'.

preacher_roles.rescuer: Low. He does not offer to 'save' the audience; he points to a model of living.
preacher_roles.persecutor: Absent. No judgment of the audience.
preacher_roles.victim: Low. He admits to being 'wounded' or 'perplexed' but does not stay in the role; he moves to Adult reflection.

drama_triangle_analysis.congregation_position: The congregation is treated as 'Members of one another' (Adults), invited to join in a collective memory.
drama_triangle_analysis.escape_possibilities: The sermon offers an escape through 'irenic' (peaceable) living and 'resonance' with God, which are presented as autonomous choices.

conclusion_and_recommendation.summary: This sermon is an exceptionally healthy example of game-free communication. It operates primarily from the Adult ego state, utilizing historical data and honest personal reflection to build a bridge to the Nurturing Parent and Free Child. By admitting his own flaws and the 'rough and tumble' of faculty life, the preacher avoids the 'holier-than-thou' Persecutor role. The use of the Ephesians text is descriptive rather than prescriptive, which prevents the listener from falling into the Adapted Child role of guilt-driven compliance.
strengths: High level of transparency and vulnerability from the preacher.
Avoidance of the 'Bait & Switch' regarding the Law.
Celebration of the 'Free Child' (humor, arts, intimacy).
areas_for_improvement: The idealization of the deceased is very high; a brief mention of Lowell's own 'Adult' struggles or limitations could further ground the sermon in reality.
conclusion_and_recommendation.advice_for_game_free_communication: Continue using the 'I' voice when discussing spiritual growth. By sharing your own process of 'coming to terms' with the tradition, you invite the congregation into an Adult-Adult partnership of discovery.
